subtitle: The Deerfield village board unanimously passed an ordinance banning certain types of assault weapons and high-capacity magazines.
author: Arturo Garcia
statement: Officials in the village of Deerfield, Illinois passed an ordinance banning assault weapons.

title: Did Facebook Suspend the Account of the Whistleblower Who Exposed Cambridge Analytica?
subtitle: The social media giant suspended Christopher Wylie's account after he went public with accusations that the psychographics firm abused the platform.
author: Bethania Palma
statement: Whistleblower Christopher Wylie's Facebook account was suspended after he came forward with allegations that Cambridge Analytica improperly acquired users' profile data.

title: Did Channing Tatum and Jenna Dewan Break Up?
subtitle: The celebrity couple announced they had "lovingly chosen to separate" in April 2018.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: Actor Channing Tatum and dancer and actor Jenna Dewan announced their separation in April 2018.

title: Does Facebook Categorize Users By Political Preferences?
subtitle: A graphic circulating online in March 2018 brought new attention to one of the company's data-gathering tools.
author: Arturo Garcia
statement: There is a section of every Facebook user profile that attempts to list them by political category.

title: Is There a Dedicated Hall & Oates Phone Line?
subtitle: A trivia-loving Facebook page accurately shares the joy of "Callin' Oates."
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: Dialing a Colorado Springs-area phone number allows you to listen to one of four Hall & Oates songs.

title: Is There a Point in the Ocean Where the Closest Human Could Be an Astronaut?
subtitle: Point Nemo is the point in the ocean furthest from any land, but it's not the only place where an astronaut might be the closest person nearby.
author: Alex Kasprak
statement: There is a point in the middle of the Pacific Ocean so far from land that it's likely the closest humans to it are aboard the International Space Station.

title: Did Roseanne Barr Pose as Adolf Hitler for a Magazine Photo Shoot?
subtitle: Controversial images of the comedian were originally published in a 2009 issue of a satire publication catering to young Jewish readers.
author: Dan Evon
statement: Roseanne Barr posed as Hitler for an issue of satirical Jewish magazine 'Heeb.'

title: Did Planned Parenthood Say There Should Be a Disney Princess Who Had an Abortion?
subtitle: Screenshots of a purported Planned Parenthood tweet circulated that appear to suggest a controversial idea for a Disney heroine.
author: Kim LaCapria
statement: A Planned Parenthood affiliate published a tweet opining that there should be a Disney princess who had an abortion.

title: Was Emma González Wearing a Cuban Flag Patch During Her 'March for Our Lives' Speech?
subtitle: An image of the Parkland school shooting attack survivor attempts to cast her as a "communist" for paying respect to her father's heritage.
author: Arturo Garcia
statement: Emma González wore a Cuban flag patch on her jacket while speaking at the March for Our Lives rally in March 2018.

title: Was Joe's Crab Shack Criticized for Displaying a Picture of a Man Being Hanged?
subtitle: A 2016 incident at a Minneapolis location of the food chain has since been recirculated through social media.
author: Arturo Garcia
statement: The Joe's Crab Shack restaurant chain was criticized after a picture of a man being hanged was discovered on its table decor.

title: Did Hundreds of Doctors in Canada Protest Against Their Own Pay Raise?
subtitle: A group of medical professionals in Quebec opposed a pay deal struck with the provincial government, but they are in the minority.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: In February and March 2018, hundreds of Canadian doctors signed a petition asking for the cancellation of pay deals from which they would personally benefit.

title: Did President Barack Obama Congratulate Putin on His 2012 Win?
subtitle: After President Donald Trump was criticized for congratulating Vladimir Putin on the results of Russia's election, claims appeared that Obama had done the same in 2012.
author: Kim LaCapria
statement: President Obama congratulated Vladimir Putin for Russia's election results in 2012, a diplomatic move for which President Trump was criticized in 2018.

title: Did Police in Delaware Shoot and Kill a Man in a Wheelchair?
subtitle: Jeremy McDole's death in 2015 received renewed attention online in 2018.
author: Arturo Garcia
statement: Police in Wilmington, Delaware shot and killed a man who was in a wheelchair at the time of the encounter.

title: Did a Firearms-Trained Teacher Accidentally Discharge a Gun in a Classroom, Injuring a Student?
subtitle: The accidental handgun firing in California was one of two such incidents at schools in the United States one day before scheduled student walkouts across the nation to protest gun violence.
author: David Emery
statement: A teacher trained in the use of firearms accidentally discharged a handgun in a California classroom, causing minor injury to a student.

title: Did a GOP Candidate Insult a Parkland Shooting Survivor on Twitter?
subtitle: Leslie Gibson, a Republican candidate Maine's House of Representatives, called Parkland school shooting survivor Emma Gonzalez a "skinhead" and a "lesbian."
author: Kim LaCapria
statement: Maine legislature candidate Leslie Gibson insulted Parkland shooting survivor and activist Emma Gonzalez via Twitter.

title: Did an Oakland Café Refuse to Serve Police Officers?
subtitle: The Hasta Muerte coffee shop told a law enforcement officer that he and his colleagues are not welcome there.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: In February 2018, the owners of a café in Oakland, California said they would not be serving police officers and would be asking them to leave.

title: Did a Trump Golf Course Use the Presidential Seal on Tee Markers?
subtitle: Social media images stoked controversy and legal questions over the Trump Organization's apparent commercial use of the seal.
author: David Emery
statement: Tee markers emblazoned with the U.S. presidential seal were manufactured for and installed at a golf course owned by the Trump Organization.

title: Did Former Trump Adviser Carl Icahn Dump Millions in Stock Before Steel Tariffs Were Announced?
subtitle: The billionaire investor and sometime Trump regulatory reform adviser insists he had no prior knowledge of President Trump's tariff announcement.
author: David Emery
statement: Billionaire investor and former Trump adviser Carl Icahn sold off approximately $30 million worth of stock in a steel-dependent company in the weeks leading up to the president's announcement of tariffs on steel imports.

title: Was Ex-California State Senator and Gun Control Advocate Leland Yee Arrested for Gun Trafficking?
subtitle: Yee pleaded guilty to arms trafficking in 2016.
author: Bethania Palma
statement: Former California state senator Leland Yee, a gun control advocate, was arrested for gun trafficking.

title: Was a Young Girl Decapitated by a Seat Belt in a Car Crash?
subtitle: A website that publishes viral content accurately recounts the terrible story of Katie Flynn's death in 2005.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: Katie Flynn was decapitated while wearing a seat belt, in a 2005 car crash on Long Island, New York.

title: Did Hundreds of Worshipers Attend an AR-15 Blessing Ceremony at a Church?
subtitle: The ceremony was held by an offshoot of the notorious Unification Church.
author: Bethania Palma
statement: Hundreds attended a church ceremony blessing AR-15s.

title: Did Ben Carson Purchase a $31,000 Dining Set and Charge It to HUD?
subtitle: After news reports revealed the purchase amid proposed funding cuts, the HUD secretary said he wants to cancel it.
author: Bethania Palma
statement: HUD Secretary Ben Carson's office bought a $31,000 dining set and billed taxpayers for it.

title: Did a Transgender Teen Boy Win a Girls' State Wrestling Title?
subtitle: Mack Beggs's request to compete in the boys' division was stymied by Texas state officials.
author: Arturo Garcia
statement: A transgender boy won a state title in girls' high school wrestling.

title: Does Iowa Grant Gun Permits to Blind People?
subtitle: Reports about a 2011 change to Iowa's gun licensing rules in Iowa went viral after a mass school shooting in 2018.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: In Iowa, blind people are legally allowed to own and possess firearms.

title: Was a Violently Racist Carnival Game Once Popular in America?
subtitle: In the not-so-distant past, white carnival goers threw eggs or balls at African Americans in a game popularly known as "Hit the N----- Baby."
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: "Hit the Nigger Baby" was once a popular attraction at fairgrounds in the United States.

title: Did the NRA Support a 1967 'Open Carry' Ban in California?
subtitle: A law barring the open carry of loaded firearms was passed in 1967 with the support of the National Rifle Association, after armed Black Panthers "invaded" the California state capitol earlier that year.
author: David Emery
statement: The National Rifle Association supported the passage of a 1967 bill in the California legislature banning the open carry of loaded firearms in public.

title: Is the NRA a Tax-Exempt Nonprofit Organization?
subtitle: A Facebook meme gets the basic facts right about the gun lobby's status as a social welfare organization.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: The NRA is a tax-exempt nonprofit organization.

title: Is a School Walkout Planned in Response to the Parkland Mass Shooting?
subtitle: School walkouts and a protest in Washington, D.C. are being planned in response to a deadly February 2018 school shooting in Florida.
author: Kim LaCapria
statement: School walkouts and protests are planned in response to the Parkland school shooting on 14 February 2018, which killed seventeen people.

title: Did the NRA Ask Judicial Candidates for 'Position Letters' on Guns?
subtitle: The National Rifle Association's letters to Wisconsin judicial candidates came under scrutiny in the wake of a mass school shooting in February 2018.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: The NRA sent Wisconsin Supreme Court candidates a letter urging them to submit a "position statement" on gun rights, or risk opposition from NRA members in the state.

title: Did Trump Use 'Crib Notes' During Listening Session with Parkland Survivors?
subtitle: A photograph showing President Trump holding notes during the listening session with survivors of the Parkland, Florida, school shooting is genuine.
author: Dan Evon
statement: A photograph shows President Trump holding crib notes during a listening session with survivors of the Parkland, Florida, school shooting.

title: Did Donald Trump Register 'Make America Great Again' in 2012?
subtitle: Donald Trump filed a trademark application for his campaign slogan in November 2012, despite claims that he had no plans to run for office at the time.
author: Alex Kasprak
statement: Donald Trump registered his "Make America Great Again" slogan in November 2012.

title: Did Donald Trump Encourage Violence at His Rallies?
subtitle: A viral cartoon accurately presented several quotations by the then-presidential candidate, delivered on the campaign trail in 2015 and 2016.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: A viral cartoon accurately reproduced statements made by Donald Trump on the presidential campaign trail.

title: Are Third-Graders Raffling Off an AR-15 After the Parkland Shooting?
subtitle: A youth baseball coach in Missouri said he wanted to make the giveaway "a positive thing."
author: Arturo Garcia
statement: A baseball team for third-graders in Neosho, Missouri is raffling off an AR-15 rifle even after it was used to commit the mass shooting in Parkland, Florida.

title: Did a Florida Gun Owner Turn in His AR-57 After the Parkland School Shooting?
subtitle: Saying "no one without a law enforcement badge needs this rifle," Ben Dickmann surrendered his weapon to the sheriff's office.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: A Florida gun owner voluntarily gave up his AR-57 rifle to law enforcement after the Parkland school shooting.

title: No School Shootings in the United Kingdom Since Handguns Were Banned?
subtitle: After a massacre at Dunblane Primary School in 1996, there have been no school shootings in the UK.
author: Kim LaCapria
statement: After a gunman killed schoolchildren and a teacher in Scotland in 1996, the UK banned handguns; no school shootings have taken place there since.

title: Did the Florida Shooter's Instagram Profile Picture Feature a 'MAGA' Hat?
subtitle: A photograph purportedly showing Nikolas Cruz in a red "Make America Great Again" hat was taken from his Instagram account.
author: Dan Evon
statement: An Instagram account linked to suspected shooter Nikolas Cruz featured an avatar that included a "MAGA" hat.

title: Was the FBI Tipped Off About the Parkland Shooter?
subtitle: A Mississippi YouTube user contacted law enforcement after a disturbing comment appeared on one of his videos.
author: Arturo Garcia
statement: The FBI received a warning about about suspected killer in the Parkland, Florida, school shooting.

title: Did a Former Canadian Official Say the Illuminati Are Real-And Hiding Alien Stuff?
subtitle: Canada's former minister of defense has long espoused conspiracy theories.
author: Bethania Palma
statement: A former Canadian defense minister said aliens have visited earth and have technology that would solve climate change, but won't share it with humans because we are too destructive.

title: Does the White House Want to Turn the International Space Station into a Commercial Venture?
subtitle: President Donald Trump has proposed entirely privatizing the International Space Station by 2025, though details on how this would occur are murky at best.
author: Alex Kasprak
statement: President Trump has proposed defunding NASA's interest in the International Space Station to allow for commercial development of the asset.

title: Did Obama's Portraitist Paint an Image of a Black Woman Holding the Severed Head of a White Person?
subtitle: Artist Kehinde Wiley is best known for reimagining classical heroic paintings using black men and women as his subjects.
author: David Emery
statement: Kehinde Wiley, the artist who painted former President Barack Obama's official portrait, also produced a pair of paintings depicting black women decapitating white people.

title: Was 'America First' a Slogan of the Ku Klux Klan?
subtitle: The white supremacist group made frequent use of the slogan more recently embraced by President Donald Trump, though they did not, as some claim, invent it.
author: David Emery
statement: President Trump's oft-repeated slogan "America First" was also a credo of the white supremacist Ku Klux Klan organization.

title: Has Rep. Joe Kennedy Received $348,000 in Donations from the Pharmaceutical Industry?
subtitle: A meme targeting the Democratic lawmaker gets some, but not all, of the facts right.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: Over the course of his career, Democratic Congressman Joe Kennedy has received $348,000 in campaign contributions from the pharmaceutical industry.

title: Does This Video Show Trump's Hair Blowing in the Wind?
subtitle: Much ado was made on social media about the President's hair after a video aired of his boarding Air Force One on a windy day.
author: Dan Evon
statement: A video shows President Trump's hair getting blown in the wind, revealing a large bald spot.

title: Is This Car Really in Space?
subtitle: A series of images showing a Tesla Roadster looking down on earth from space are real.
author: Dan Evon
statement: A series of images show a Tesla vehicle in space.

title: Did a Pennsylvania Teacher Assign Math Homework That Referred to Sexual Assault?
subtitle: Students at Pennridge High School were asked to solve algebra formulas using vignettes from the difficult early life of Maya Angelou; Internet outrage ensued.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: A teacher assigned math homework that included references to sexual assault and prostitution.

title: Did a Study Show That Dogs Exhibit Jealousy?
subtitle: A popular meme showing a dog looking resentful as his owner poses with a significant other is based on a 2014 study suggesting dogs can behave jealously.
author: Arturo Garcia
statement: A study showed that dogs could show jealousy if they caught their owners behaving sweetly toward other dogs.

title: Did Armed Trump Supporters Ask a Navajo Legislator If He's 'Legal'?
subtitle: Video footage shows an anti-immigration protester aggressively questioning Arizona state Rep. Eric Descheenie about his citizenship status.
author: Bethania Palma
statement: Armed Trump supporters protesting immigration demanded to know if a Native American legislator is in the United States "legally."

title: Did Billy Graham Warn Against Mixing Religion and Politics?
subtitle: The evangelical leader said in a 1981 profile that people in his position "can't be closely identified with any particular party or person."
author: Arturo Garcia
statement: Rev. Billy Graham once said, "The hard right has no interest in religion except to manipulate it."

title: Does MIT Offer Students a 'Pirate Certificate'?
subtitle: The prestigious university counts among its alumni Nobel laureates, leaders of science and industry, and a fleet of certified swashbucklers.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: MIT offers a "pirate certificate" to students who complete four physical education courses.

title: Did United Airlines Deny a Passenger's Request to Fly with an Emotional Support Peacock?
subtitle: The answer to the age-old question "Can peacocks fly?" is yes - but not on United Airlines.
author: David Emery
statement: A woman seeking to bring her peacock along on a flight as an emotional support animal was denied permission to do so by United Airlines.

title: Did Democrats Check Their Phones During Trump's State of the Union Address?
subtitle: A meme showing lawmakers checking their phones during the State of the Union is real - but this is not unprecedented, uncommon, or confined to one political party.
author: Dan Evon
statement: A few Democratic lawmakers were spotted checking their phones during President Trump's State of the Union address.

title: Did a California Teacher Call Military Members 'the Lowest of Our Low'?
subtitle: Gregory Salcido, who is also a City Council member in Pico Rivera, was caught on video making a series of controversial remarks about the armed services.
author: Bethania Palma
statement: California schoolteacher Gregory Salcido called members of the United States military "the lowest of our low" during a classroom discussion.

title: Did Marcel Marceau Save Hundreds of Jewish Children From Nazis?
subtitle: The Frenchman who would become known as the world's greatest pantomime artist helped smuggle Jewish children to safety in Switzerland during World War II.
author: David Emery
statement: The world-famous mime artist Marcel Marceau worked with the French underground as a teenager and help save many Jewish children from death at the hands of the Nazis during World War II.

title: Will President Trump Display the Names of Campaign Donors During the State of the Union?
subtitle: If you donate to President Donald Trump's re-election, your name will appear during a campaign-run livestream of his State of the Union address.
author: Alex Kasprak
statement: President Trump offered that those who donated to his reelection could have their name displayed during a Trump campaign-run livestream of the State of the Union address

title: Misspelled Tickets Issued for 'State of the Uniom' Address?
subtitle: Sitting senators tweeted images of the misspelled tickets on 29 January 2018.
author: David Emery
statement: Tickets issued for President Trump's first State of the Union address contain a misspelling of the word "union."

title: Will There Be A 'Super Blue Blood Moon' This Week?
subtitle: NASA has called the astronomical event in late January 2018 a "supermoon trilogy."
author: Alex Kasprak
statement: A rare confluence of celestial events will bring what NASA terms a “super blue blood moon” to the skies on 31 January 2018.

title: Is a New York Lawmaker Accused of Sexual Misconduct Negotiating Anti-Harassment Laws?
subtitle: A former staffer said the senator forced himself on her outside a bar in April 2015.
author: Arturo Garcia
statement: Sen. Jeff Klein (D-New York) is part of negotiations regarding anti-sexual harassment laws - after he was accused of the same offense.

title: Did a Vermont Woman Post a Joke About Trump 'Bringing Back Slavery'?
subtitle: Heather Wick faced an online backlash after a racially insensitive Facebook post in 2017, and again in 2018.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: Heather Wick joked about having a slave as a maid in a January 2017 Facebook post.

title: United States Senate Candidate Favors a Woman's Right to Cook Him Dinner?
subtitle: Decrying a "non-stop feminization campaign against manhood," a GOP Senate candidate said he supports a woman's right to "become traditional homemakers."
author: Alex Kasprak
statement: A Republican candidate for U.S. Senate for Missouri, Courtland Sykes, said he "supports women's rights" but not if that means women become "career obsessed banshees who forego home life and children and the happiness of family to become nail-biting manophobic hell-bent feminist she devils."

title: Did the Kochs Contribute $500,000 to Paul Ryan After the GOP Tax Plan Was Passed?
subtitle: Charles and Elizabeth Koch gave nearly half a million dollars to the House Speaker's fundraising committee after passage of the Republican tax bill.
author: Alex Kasprak
statement: Charles and Elizabeth Koch contributed nearly $500,000 to Paul Ryan's fundraising committee after the GOP tax plan passed in the U.S. House of Representatives.

title: Did Customs Agents Board a Bus in Florida Asking for Proof of Citizenship?
subtitle: An encounter captured on video in January 2018 depicts a longstanding practice by immigration officials.
author: Arturo Garcia
statement: Customs agents boarded a Greyhound bus and asked passengers for proof of citizenship.

title: Does Congress Get Paid While Military Personnel Do Not During a Government Shutdown?
subtitle: Unlike military pay, which is appropriated annually, paychecks for House and Senate members are guaranteed by the U.S. Constitution, even during a shutdown.
author: David Emery
statement: Members of Congress continue to get paid but military personnel do not during a U.S. government shutdown.

title: Did the White House Change Outgoing Message on Comment Line to Blame Democrats?
subtitle: The unprecedented finger-pointing took place amid a government shutdown and looming government worker furloughs.
author: Brooke Binkowski
statement: The White House updated the voice message on the automated telephone comments line to blame Democrats for a government shutdown.

title: Did Trump Criticize Obama for a Lack of Leadership During the 2013 Government Shutdown?
subtitle: Who's most to blame for failing to "get everyone in a room" to "make a deal" when a government shutdown looms?
author: David Mikkelson
statement: Donald Trump criticized President Barack Obama during the 2013 government shutdown for failing to "lead," "get everyone in a room," and "make a deal."

title: Did President Trump Decry Babies Being 'Born in the Ninth Month'?
subtitle: The president apparently misspoke while delivering remarks to the 45th March for Life in Washington.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: President Trump said that a number of state laws allow a baby 'to be born from his or her mother's womb in the ninth month.'

title: Sushi Fanatic Pulls 5-Foot-Long Tapeworm Out of His Body
subtitle: The attending physician confirmed that a patient walked into the emergency room with the giant parasite wrapped around a toilet paper tube.
author: David Emery
statement: A Fresno man turned up at a local emergency room carrying a 5-foot-long tapeworm he pulled out of his own intestine.

title: Did Sen. Tom Cotton Issue a 'Cease and Desist' Letter to a Constituent?
subtitle: The Arkansas Republican's office says such letters are "only used under extreme circumstances."
author: Arturo Garcia
statement: Sen. Tom Cotton's office has sent "cease-and-desist" letters to constituents ordering them not to contact him.

title: Is 'Bluetooth' Technology Named After a Viking King?
subtitle: The name of the wireless technology standard apparently originated during a Toronto pub crawl one dark and stormy night.
author: Brooke Binkowski
statement: The name "Bluetooth," which refers to the standard for shortrange wireless connections, is derived from Viking king Harald Gormsson, who is credited with uniting Scandinavia.

title: Will Health and Human Services Allow Doctors to Refuse to Treat LGBTQ Patients?
subtitle: The department cited a judge's December 2016 ruling that does not extend patient protections to cover gender identity.
author: Arturo Garcia
statement: A new division of the Department of Health and Human Services will allow doctors to refuse to treat LGBTQ patients for religious reasons.

title: Donald Trump Sold an Apartment to a Brutal Haitian Dictator?
subtitle: He sold the Trump Tower apartment to Jean-Claude "Baby Doc" Duvalier through a Panamanian shell corporation in 1983.
author: Alex Kasprak
statement: Donald Trump sold a Trump Tower apartment to the brutal and corrupt former Haitian leader Jean-Claude “Baby Doc” Duvalier.

title: Did San Diego Hire a 'Rainmaker' to End a Drought in 1916?
subtitle: Self-styled "moisture accelerator" Charles Hatfield promised to fill the city's depleted reservoirs using a secret formula and 35-foot-tall "evaporating towers."
author: David Emery
statement: In December 1915, San Diego agreed to pay $10,000 to "rainmaker" Charles Hatfield to bring an end to the region's drought; over the next few weeks the city was inundated by rain and suffered one of the worst floods in its history.

title: Emmanuel Mensah's Final Act of Heroism
subtitle: Emmanuel Mensah was a United States Army soldier and immigrant from Ghana who died saving his neighbors' lives during the 2017 Bronx fire.
author: Alex Kasprak
statement: A Ghanaian immigrant and United States Army private named Emmanuel Mensah died after saving multiple lives in a Bronx apartment building fire.

title: Did Botswana Condemn Trump's Alleged 'Shithole' Slur Toward African Countries?
subtitle: The country's government, as well as a union representing the entire continent, called for an apology from the president.
author: Arturo Garcia
statement: Botswana condemned President Donald Trump's alleged remarks calling African nations "shithole countries."

title: Is the 'Tide Pod Challenge' a Real Thing?
subtitle: Yes, people really are putting laundry detergent in their mouths and posting videos online.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: The "Tide pod challenge" is a real viral phenomenon whereby people bite into Tide brand laundry detergent pods.

title: Is 'Trumpy Bear' a Real Product?
subtitle: As seen on TV: "The fearless, super-plush American grizzly"
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: A stuffed animal called "Trumpy Bear" is a real product available for purchase.

title: Did IKEA Release an Advertisement Containing a Pregnancy Test?
subtitle: The ad allows expectant mothers to use their urine to reveal a coupon for a crib.
author: Arturo Garcia
statement: IKEA released a magazine ad which includes a pregnancy test.

title: Another 'Amazing' 2018 Calendar Quirk?
subtitle: Two important Christian observances fall on dates that are also secular holidays in 2018.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: Two observances important to Christianity fall on Valentine's Day and April Fools' Day in 2018.

title: Did 'The Boondocks' Forecast Oprah Winfrey's Becoming President?
subtitle: A 2006 episode of the Cartoon Network series received a surge in attention after the talk show host's Golden Globes speech twelve years later.
author: Arturo Garcia
statement: Animated series "The Boondocks" had a scene about Oprah Winfrey's becoming president in 2020.

title: Was 'Dixie' Taken Out of Dolly Parton's Dixie Stampede Dinner Attraction?
subtitle: Critics said that the show romanticized the pre-Civil War South; supporters, in turn decried the reign of "political correctness."
author: Bethania Palma
statement: The word "Dixie" was removed from a popular Civil War-themed dinner show in Tennessee.

title: Are Essential Oils Poisonous to Pets?
subtitle: Medical experts back a woman's warning that eucalyptus and other oils can be harmful to pets.
author: Arturo Garcia
statement: Essential oils can be poisonous to pets.

title: Do These Photographs Show Snowfall in the Sahara Desert?
subtitle: The meteorological phenomenon is rare but not unprecedented.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: Photographs show snow in the Sahara Desert in January 2018.

title: Was Oprah Pictured Kissing Harvey Weinstein on the Cheek?
subtitle: A photograph showing Oprah offering Harvey Weinstein a peck on the cheek is real; it was taken in 2014 at the Critics' Choice movie awards.
author: Dan Evon
statement: A photograph shows Oprah Winfrey kissing Harvey Weinstein on the cheek.

title: Will A Defunct Chinese Space Station Crash Into Earth in March 2018?
subtitle: Researchers agree that an inactive Chinese space station will probably crash back to Earth by mid-March 2018, but it's nothing to worry about.
author: Alex Kasprak
statement: A defunct Chinese space station is expected to fall back to Earth in mid-March 2018.

title: Yes, Joanna Gaines from 'Fixer Upper' Is Pregnant
subtitle: Joanna and Chip Gaines, stars of the home improvement reality TV show, made the announcement on social media.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: 'Fixer Upper' star Joanna Gaines is pregnant with her fifth child in January 2018.

title: Did the City of Seattle Add a 'Sweetened Beverage Recovery Fee'?
subtitle: Distributors of sweetened drinks in the Emerald City now have to pay an excise tax of 1.75 cents per fluid ounce.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: Seattle has imposed an excise tax on the distributors of sweetened drinks.

title: Did Chelsea Clinton Tweet 'Happy New Year' to the Church of Satan?
subtitle: How the daughter of a former president wound up in the company of a supermodel and the Church of Satan in a Twitter thread for the ages.
author: David Emery
statement: In a 2 January 2018 Twitter thread, Chelsea Clinton wished the Church of Satan a Happy New Year.

title: Did Hurricane Maria Cause an IV Bag Shortage Across the United States?
subtitle: A California man's account brought to light one of the lesser-known aftereffects of the fatal storm.
author: Arturo Garcia
statement: United States health care facilities face an intravenous bag shortage because of the devastation wreaked by Hurricane Maria in September 2017.

title: Did President Trump Roll Back Rules Protecting Elderly at Nursing Homes?
subtitle: The Trump administration scaled back an Obama-era policy of levying heavy fines against nursing homes that harm patients.
author: Bethania Palma
statement: President Trump rolled back rules protecting residents of nursing homes.

title: Did Michael Jordan Sue a Grocery Store for $10 Million?
subtitle: The former NBA superstar won a hefty award in 2015 after filing suit against the Dominick's grocery chain for using his name in an advertisement without his permission.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: Former NBA superstar won a hefty award in 2015 after filing suit against a grocery chain that used his name in an advertisement without his permission.

title: Did Trump Put 'Make America Great Again' on Presidential Challenge Coins?
subtitle: Past designs of the tokens, have been subtler and included the phrase 'E pluribus unum.'
author: Megan Alpert
statement: Redesigned challenge coins given out by President Trump replaced the familiar 'E pluribus unum' motto with Trump's campaign slogan.

title: Was Fake Snow Made from Asbestos Marketed as Christmas Decor?
subtitle: Asbestos was widely used for a variety of purposes before it was recognized as a significant carcinogen.
author: Bethania Palma
statement: A photograph shows vintage box of fake snow decor made of the carcinogen asbestos.

title: Are No Two Snowflakes Exactly Alike?
subtitle: Your elementary school teachers weren't lying to you -- this oft-repeated phrase is correct, but it is likely applicable to almost anything larger than a single atom.
author: Alex Kasprak
statement: No two snowflakes are exactly alike.

title: Did 'View' Host Joy Behar Grab Robin Williams by the Crotch?
subtitle: A 2006 photograph shows Behar and Williams cutting up with fellow comedians Billy Crystal and Whoopi Goldberg.
author: Bethania Palma
statement: A 2006 photograph shows 'The View' host Joy Behar grabbing Robin Williams' crotch.

title: Does a Viral Video Show a Polar Bear Starving to Death?
subtitle: Upsetting footage captured on Canada's Baffin Island is authentic, but the role of climate change in this particular animal's suffering is complicated.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: A video shows a sick, possibly starving polar bear on Baffin Island in the Canadian Arctic.

title: Does the 2017 Tax Plan Eliminate Deduction for Losses from Wildfires, Other Natural Disasters?
subtitle: Blowback against the proposed elimination of deductions for personal losses caused by natural disasters surged as wildfires ravaged southern California.
author: David Emery
statement: The Tax Cuts and Jobs Act of 2017 calls for eliminating or severely curtailing the personal casualty deduction for losses from wildfires and other natural disasters.

title: Did Police in Georgia Force a Man to Cut Off His Own Dog's Head?
subtitle: The incident, which included police orders and threats of arrest, was captured on video.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: Police in Crawford County, Georgia forced local man Joe Nathan Goodwin, under threat of arrest, to cut off his own dog's head for rabies testing after police fatally shot the dog.

title: Does the 2017 Tax Reform Bill Help Private Schools and Hurt Public Schools?
subtitle: The legislation grants tax breaks to families with children in private schools, while repealing deductions for state and local taxes that fund public schools.
author: David Emery
statement: The 2017 tax reform bill eliminates personal deductions for state and local taxes (primary sources of public school funding), while offering tax breaks for parents who send their children to private schools.

title: Did an Alabama Church Display a Sign Comparing Roy Moore to Jesus?
subtitle: Living Way Ministries said its pastor did not approve of the sign, but at least two other churches were also caught using a blatantly political sign.
author: Arturo Garcia
statement: The billboard for Living Way Ministries in Alabama displayed a message openly supporting GOP senatorial candidate Roy Moore.

title: Did Walmart Sell Shirts That Allude to Hanging Journalists?
subtitle: The retailer removed the shirt after receiving a complaint from the Radio Television Digital News Association.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: Walmart temporarily sold a shirt bearing the words "Rope. Tree. Journalist. Some Assembly Required."

title: Did Shane Patrick Boyle Die After Fundraising to Pay for Insulin?
subtitle: Reports concerning a man who passed away shortly after starting a GoFundMe crowdsourcing campaign to raise money for insulin were met with some skepticism.
author: Dan Evon
statement: A man named Shane Patrick Boyle died shortly after starting a GoFundMe fundraiser for insulin.

title: Does The Republican Tax Bill Include a Tax Loophole Benefitting Golf Course Owners?
subtitle: The "conservation easement" deduction is part of the GOP's current tax legislation -- but it is not a recent addition.
author: Arturo Garcia
statement: The Republican-sponsored Tax Cuts and Jobs Act includes a deduction benefitting golf course owners.

title: Does a 'Call of Duty: WWII' Still Show Two Men Hanging From a Tree?
subtitle: A screenshot from the game showing a shocking scene is genuine.
author: Dan Evon
statement: An image showing two lynched men originated with the game "Call of Duty: WWII."

title: United States to Reverse Ban on Wildlife Trophies?
subtitle: The U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service announced it was reversing a ban on the import of legally-hunted elephant trophies from Zimbabwe and Zambia, then put a hold on the decision pending further review.
author: Snopes Staff
statement: The United States will reverse restrictions on bringing back legally-hunted elephant trophies.

title: Does This Photograph Show a Group of Deported U.S. Veterans?
subtitle: A picture of veterans in Mexico who were deported after serving the U.S. military was met with some skepticism.
author: Dan Evon
statement: A photograph shows a group of deported U.S. veterans in the Mexican border city of Ciudad Juárez.

title: Oregon's Infamous Exploding Whale
subtitle: The Oregon Department of Transportation once tried to remove a troublesome dead whale from the shoreline by blowing it up, with calamitous results.
author: Snopes Staff
statement: In 1970, the Oregon Department of Transportation attempted to dispose of a whale carcass by blowing it up.

title: Did Roy Moore Say Muslims Shouldn't Be Allowed to Serve in Congress?
subtitle: The U.S. Senate candidate wrote in 2006 that newly-elected Representative Keith Ellison, a Muslim, should be prohibited from taking the oath of office.
author: David Emery
statement: U.S. Senate candidate from Alabama Roy Moore said that a practicing Muslim should not be allowed to serve in Congress by reason of his faith.

title: Is This a Picture of André the Giant Holding a Beer Can?
subtitle: Big hands or small can?  Inquiring minds want to know.
author: Dan Evon
statement: A photograph shows André the Giant holding a 12-oz. can of beer.

title: Does the California NAACP Want to Replace the National Anthem?
subtitle: The group has proposed state legislation aimed at replacing "The Star-Spangled Banner" as the national anthem due to its controversial third stanza.
author: Alex Kasprak
statement: The California NAACP is seeking to replace "The Star-Spangled Banner' as the national anthem of the United States due to concerns over its racist overtones and history.

title: Is The Southern Baptist Convention Covering Funeral Costs for Sutherland Springs Victims?
subtitle: The primary missions agency of the Southern Baptist Convention will cover any out-of-pocket funeral costs not met by a victim's compensation fund.
author: Alex Kasprak
statement: The Southern Baptist Convention has offered to pay for the funeral costs of any victim of the Sutherland Springs, Texas mass shooting.

title: Is Clothing Retailer Marshalls Still Paying Employees in Puerto Rico?
subtitle: A Facebook post brought attention to the retail chain's treatment of workers after Hurricane Maria.
author: Arturo Garcia
statement: Marshalls employees in Puerto Rico are still being paid despite the damage to stores there caused by Hurricane Maria.

title: Does President Trump Plan to 'End' a Program Funding Heating for the Elderly and Disabled?
subtitle: The White House has proposed eliminating funding for LIHEAP, which serves around 6 million households.
author: Arturo Garcia
statement: President Donald Trump has proposed eliminating funding for a program helping low-income families with their heating bills.

title: Pins and Needles in Halloween Candy
subtitle: Pins, needles and razor blades been occasionally been found in trick-or-treaters' loot over the years.
author: Snopes Staff
statement: Pins, needles, and razor blades have been found in trick-or-treaters' loot.

title: Were Real Skeletons Used in the Making of 'Poltergeist'?
subtitle: The film's special effects makeup artist revealed one of the secrets behind one of the horror classic's sequences in a deposition.
author: Arturo Garcia
statement: Real skeletons were used for a sequence in the horror movie "Poltergeist."

title: Did John Wayne Say He Believed in White Supremacy?
subtitle: The quote from iconic Western actor John Wayne came from a 1971 interview with "Playboy" magazine.
author: Dan Evon
statement: John Wayne said that he believed in white supremacy during an interview with "Playboy" magazine.

title: Did a Hungry Homeless Man Who Stole $100 Receive a Far Heavier Sentence Than a White-Collar Thief?
subtitle: An article contrasted the disparate sentences given to a homeless man and a corporate investor.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: An article contrasts the disparate sentences given to Roy Brown and Paul R. Allen.

title: Was a Veterans Day Tribute at Lambeau Field Not Aired by ESPN?
subtitle: Television exposure of 'entertainers' before NFL games and at halftime can't be guaranteed.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: Photographs show a 2011 NFL Veterans Day tribute that ESPN omitted from their pre-game coverage.

title: Does This Photograph Show Beetles Embedded in a Dog's Mouth?
subtitle: A shocking image was circulated with a warning to pet owners to check their dogs' mouths for beetles.
author: Dan Evon
statement: A photograph shows insects embedded in a dog's mouth.

title: Did a City in Texas Require Harvey Aid Recipients to Promise Not to Boycott Israel?
subtitle: The mayor of Dickinson, Texas, says a new state law requires that the city ask aid recipients not to boycott Israel.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: As of October 2017, would-be recipients of a repair grant from Dickinson, Texas, must promise not to boycott Israel.

title: Did a Football Fan Sit on an American Flag While Wearing a Shirt Reading 'I Stand for the National Anthem'?
subtitle: A sports news web site published the photograph, which was taken during a game between the New York Jets and the New England Patriots.
author: Arturo Garcia
statement: A pro football fan sat on the United States flag while wearing a shirt that read: "I stand for the national anthem."

title: Did Hugh Hefner Pay to be Interred Next to Marilyn Monroe?
subtitle: The magazine mogul paid $75,000 to be laid to rest beside the actress, who was (unwillingly) the first Playboy centerfold.
author: Arturo Garcia
statement: Hugh Hefner paid $75,000 to be interred next to Marilyn Monroe in a Los Angeles cemetery.

title: Did the U.S. Ban Lawn Dart Sales After One Child's Death?
subtitle: A 1988 decision about a backyard game has been used to highlight ongoing political inaction around guns after mass shootings.
author: Arturo Garcia
statement: The U.S. government banned the sale of lawn darts in the aftermath of a child's death in 1987.

title: Was a Detroit Firefighter Fired for Bringing a Watermelon to His Station?
subtitle: Detroit's fire commissioner confirmed that a probationary firefighter was terminated for work behavior deemed "offensive and racially insensitive."
author: David Emery
statement: A Detroit firefighter was fired for behavior deemed offensive and racially insensitive after bringing a watermelon to work on his first day on the job.

title: Did the CEO of Hardwick Clothes Cut Ties With the NFL Over 'Unpatriotic' Protests?
subtitle: News reports accurately describe a decision made by Tennessee businessman Allan Jones.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: In September 2017, Tennessee businessman and CEO of Hardwick Clothes Allan Jones withdrew all NFL-related advertising for his companies, in response to "unpatriotic" national anthem protests.

title: Did the Hollywood Reporter Criticize Actors Who Opposed Nazi Germany in 1937?
subtitle: The newspaper's managing editor chided stars who he said were courting "unpopularity" by speaking out against Hitler's regime.
author: Arturo Garcia
statement: The Hollywood Reporter published a column in 1937 criticizing actors for speaking out against Nazi Germany.

title: Pregnant Smoker Complains About Construction Noise?
subtitle: A infamously viral newspaper photograph shows a pregnant woman smoking a cigarette and complaining about the effects of construction noise on her unborn child.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: A newspaper photograph shows a pregnant, cigarette-smoking woman worrying about the effect of construction noise on her unborn child.

title: Did a U.S. Veteran Influence Kaepernick's 'Take a Knee' Protest of Police Brutality?
subtitle: Green Beret and NFL player Nate Boyer confirmed he convinced the quarterback to "take a knee," rather than sit, during the national anthem.
author: Arturo Garcia
statement: U.S. Army veteran Nate Boyer convinced Colin Kaepernick to kneel, rather than sit, while protesting police brutality during the national anthem.

title: Can Some Horses Grow Mustaches?
subtitle: Some hirsute equines can indeed grow mustaches; in this case, the dapper pictures do not lie.
author: Alex Kasprak
statement: Some horses can grow mustaches.

title: Donald Trump: The President Shouldn't Tell NFL Teams What to Do?
subtitle: Critics of President Trump's focus on football players' national anthem protests have gleefully re-shared a NFL-related tweet of his from 2013.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: In 2013, Donald Trump criticized President Obama for interfering in an NFL team issue.

title: Did the Guggenheim Museum Plan to Host Exhibits Criticized by Some as Cruel to Animals?
subtitle: An online petition accurately describes the basic facts about three installations that were later removed from a Chinese art exhibition.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: The Guggenheim Museum planned to host a Chinese art exhibition that included three installations condemned as cruel to animals.

title: Did a State Democratic Party Logo Once Feature the Slogan 'White Supremacy'?
subtitle: Until 1966, the official logo of the Alabama Democratic Party featured a crowing rooster and a banner reading "White Supremacy."
author: David Emery
statement: The official logo of the Alabama Democratic Party, adopted in 1904 and not replaced until 1966, featured an illustration of a crowing rooster and the slogan "White Supremacy, For the RIght."

title: Is Healthcare.gov Scheduled for Maintenance During Obamacare Enrollment?
subtitle: News reports correctly describe the facts surrounding scheduled "Obamacare" web site downtime during November and December 2017.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: The Department of Health and Human Services has scheduled web site maintenance for Healthcare.gov on most Sundays during Obamacare open enrollment.

title: Did a 1990 Comic Depict Trump Coming to Power and Building a Wall?
subtitle: A 27-year-old comic strip by Peter Kuper received renewed interest on social media in 2017.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: A July 1990 comic strip in Heavy Metal magazine featured a controversial wall in New York City, built by Donald Trump, and a populist "rise to power" by the future president.

title: Did a Buffalo Wild Wings Worker Turn Down the National Anthem Because It Is 'Divisive'?
subtitle: The controversy was grounded in a real incident, for which the worker's employer apologized.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: On 11 September 2017, a worker at a Buffalo Wild Wings in Eastvale, California, turned down the volume on the national anthem before an NFL game, saying it was "divisive."

title: Neko Case's Farmhouse Damaged by Fire?
subtitle: Despite an initial denial from the singer, Case's farmhouse was indeed damaged in a September 2017 fire.
author: Dan Evon
statement: Musician Neko Case's Vermont farmhouse was badly damaged in a fire in September 2017.

title: 'Jeepers Creepers 3' Director Victor Salva Was Convicted of Child Molestation?
subtitle: "Jeepers Creepers 3" director Victor Salva was convicted in 1988 of molesting a 12-year-old.
author: Dan Evon
statement: Director Victor Salva was convicted of child molestation.

title: Are Black-and-White Caterpillars 'Poisonous'?
subtitle: Black and white tussock moth caterpillars can cause severe allergic reactions in some people who touch them.
author: Snopes Staff
statement: Black and white caterpillars can cause severe allergic reactions in some people who touch them.

title: Can Hurricane Victims Delay Their Mortgage Payments?
subtitle: Lenders Freddie Mac and Fannie Mae, as well as the federal government, have programs to help homeowners affected by natural disasters.
author: Arturo Garcia
statement: Homeowners affected by hurricanes are allowed, under certain circumstances, to delay their mortgage payments.

title: Scene from 'Maya the Bee' Features a Phallic Image?
subtitle: A scene from the children's show features a hidden risqué drawing on the inside of a log.
author: Dan Evon
statement: A crude sketch of a phallus could be seen on the inside of a log during an episode of

title: Did a Criminology Textbook Use Brock Turner to Illustrate an Entry on Rape?
subtitle: An image of the man convicted of sexually assaulting a woman on the Stanford University campus was used to illustrate a textbook entry on rape.
author: Dan Evon
statement: A criminology textbook used an image of Brock Turner to illustrate an entry on rape.

title: 'We Stand by You'
subtitle: U.S. naval officer's letter describes a  'manning the rails' ceremony performed by a German destroyer.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: U.S. naval officer's letter describes a  'manning the rails' ceremony performed by a German destroyer.

title: Did Hurricane Irma Draw the Water Away from Beaches in Florida and the Bahamas?
subtitle: Remarkable images appear to show examples of a real meteorological phenomenon called "negative surge."
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: Hurricane Irma had the effect of drawing water away from stretches of coastline in Florida and the Bahamas.

title: Is This a Picture of the Bitterroot Forest Fire?
subtitle: An awe-inspiring photograph reportedly captured wildlife fleeing a  fire in Bitterroot Forest, Montana.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: A photograph captures wildlife fleeing a fire in Bitterroot Forest, Montana.

title: Are These People Golfing Near a Huge Forest Fire?
subtitle: A photograph shows a group of people golfing near a large forest fire, but they aren't in as much danger as they appear.
author: Dan Evon
statement: A photograph shows a group of people golfing as a forest fire rages in the background.

title: Did the Governor of the United States' Virgin Islands Sign an Order Allowing the Seizure of Weapons During Hurricane Irma?
subtitle: Despite denials, Governor Kenneth Mapp's executive order does authorize the National Guard to seize firearms and other property -  if he deems it necessary to keep public order.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: In September 2017, U.S. Virgin Islands Governor Kenneth Mapp signed an executive order empowering the National Guard to seize weapons and other private property.

title: Can the 'FireChat' App Send Messages Without an Internet Connection?
subtitle: The app works as advertised, but it does have some distance limitations.
author: Dan Evon
statement: The FireChat app can send messages without any connection to the Internet.

title: Did Donald Trump Cut Funding for Obamacare Enrollment Publicity?
subtitle: Facebook warnings accurately describe a 90 percent budget cut for publicizing the shortened 2018 enrollment period for Obamacare.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: The Trump administration announced it would be spending 90 percent less on advertising a shortened open enrollment period for Obamacare in 2018.

title: Are There Floating Islands of Fire Ants in Hurricane-Flooded Areas of Texas?
subtitle: Their behavior is perhaps unnerving, but it is normal during floods.
author: Bethania Palma
statement: There are small islands of fire ants floating in the floodwaters from Tropical Storm Harvey.

title: Did Mexican Troops Aid the U.S. After Hurricane Katrina?
subtitle: As Hurricane Harvey hit Texas in 2017, so too did a rumor that Mexico sent troops to assist U.S. residents after Hurricane Katrina.
author: Kim LaCapria
statement: Mexican troops provided aid to U.S. residents in the chaotic aftermath of Hurricane Katrina.

title: The Body Under the Bed
subtitle: A vacationing couple staying in a foul-smelling motel room discovered a body hidden under their bed.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: A vacationing couple staying in a foul-smelling motel room discovered a body hidden under their bed.

title: Did NFL Player Isaiah Crowell Post an Image of a Police Officer Being Killed?
subtitle: The Cleveland Browns running back posted the artist's rendering to Instagram in July 2016; then quickly deleted it and repeatedly apologized.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: Cleveland Browns running back Isaiah Crowell once posted to his Instagram profile an artist's rendering of a hooded man cutting the throat of a police officer.

title: Ronald Reagan: 'If Fascism Ever Comes to America, It Will Come in the Name of Liberalism'
subtitle: The former California governor and future U.S. president made the comment during a 1975 interview with "60 Minutes" over a discussion of his economic philosophy.
author: Bethania Palma
statement: Ronald Reagan said, "If fascism ever comes to America, it will come in the name of liberalism."

title: Man Looks Like Mountain?
subtitle: A photograph purportedly showing a supine man on a beach near a mountain resembling his outline is, hilariously, genuine.
author: Dan Evon
statement: A photograph shows a man on a beach near a mountain that resembles his outline.

title: The Unsolvable Math Problem
subtitle: A student mistook examples of unsolved math problems for  a homework assignment and solved them.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: A student mistook examples of unsolved statistics problems for  a homework assignment and solved them.

title: Did Protesters Burn a Minnesota County's Flag and Raise an Anti-Fascist One at a Local Jail?
subtitle: Right-wing web sites accurately describe the basic facts of a real incident which lasted for around 30 minutes.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: On 14 August 2017, protesters removed and destroyed the county flag from the Hennepin County, Minnesota jail, and temporarily replaced it with an Antifa flag.

title: Is There a Class Action Lawsuit for People Who Got Robocalls From Cruise Companies?
subtitle: News articles accurately describe the settlement and compensation terms of a real lawsuit involving major cruise companies.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: As of August 2017, members of the public could potentially gain compensation as part of a class action lawsuit against major cruise companies.

title: Did Abraham Lincoln Express Opposition to Racial Equality?
subtitle: An authentic quote from Lincoln has attracted renewed attention, along with some commentary that oversimplifies his views on race.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: In 1858, Lincoln expressed his opposition to racial equality and asserted the superiority of white people.

title: Did the Attorney General of Alabama Once Tell the Ku Klux Klan to 'Kiss My Ass'?
subtitle: Bill Baxley wrote the famously succinct letter to a KKK Grand Dragon in 1976 in response to threats intended to intimidate him.
author: Bethania Palma
statement: The former Alabama state Attorney general, Bill Baxley, once told a Ku Klux Klan Grand Dragon "kiss my ass" in response to threats.

title: Did a Hotel Owner in Switzerland Ask Jewish Guests to Shower Before Using the Pool?
subtitle: News articles accurately describe real signs posted around a hotel in Arosa, Switzerland that were widely condemned as anti-Semitic.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: In August 2017, the owner of a hotel in Arosa, Switzerland posted signs imposing restrictions on Jewish guests, including asking them to shower before using the hotel swimming pool.

title: Did the Department of Justice Request Detailed Information About All Visitors to an Anti-Trump Website?
subtitle: A web hosting company says they are being compelled to turn over all information about an anti-Trump site that helped organize Inauguration Day protests.
author: Alex Kasprak
statement: The United States Department of Justice is attempting to seize the information of every person who ever visited the anti-trump website disruptj20.org.

title: Did Trump Retweet a Cartoon of a Train Hitting a CNN Reporter?
subtitle: President Trump retweeted, then quickly deleted, a cartoon of a train hitting a CNN reporter, leaving some to wonder if the posting was real.
author: Dan Evon
statement: President Trump retweeted a cartoon of a train hitting a CNN reporter.

title: Did a 1940s U.S. War Department Film Compare Anti-Minority Hate Speech to Nazi Propaganda?
subtitle: The World War II-era short film "Don't Be a Sucker" cited Nazi propaganda as an example of how hatred of minority groups is used to stoke political fanaticism.
author: David Emery
statement: A U.S. War Department film from the 1940s warns Americans that political rhetoric condemning minorities and foreigners is a precursor to fascist movements like Nazism.

title: Man Burns to Death Rescuing Dog from Hot Springs
subtitle: Burn deaths and injuries result from people trying to retrieve straying pets from boiling hot springs.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: A man was burned to death attempting to rescue his dog from a boiling hot spring.

title: Racist Protesters Protected by Black Policeman?
subtitle: A photograph showing a black police officer protecting participants in a white supremacist protest was widely circulated after violent events in Charlottesville, Virginia.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: A photograph shows a black police officer protecting participants in a white supremacist protest in Charlottesville.

title: Does This Photo Show a Boy with a Fork Through His Nose?
subtitle: A child's nose was impaled by a fork during a freak accident at a restaurant.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: Photographs show a boy whose nose has been impaled with a fork.

title: Did the National Debt Fall by $102 Billion After Donald Trump's Inauguration?
subtitle: A conservative web site accurately described a remarkable decline in the debt during the first half of 2017 but offered no evidence that the President was responsible for it.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: The national debt saw a "surprising" decline of $102 billion between 20 January and 27 July 2017.

title: Guam Reaches the Tipping Point?
subtitle: Rep. Hank Johnson said he feared that stationing 8,000 Marines on Guam would cause the island to 'become so overly populated that it will tip over and capsize.'
author: David Mikkelson
statement: During a House committee meeting, Rep. Hank Johnson said he feared that stationing 8,000 Marines on Guam would cause the island to "become so overly populated that it will tip over and capsize."

title: Were 'Highway Closed in Event of Enemy Attack' Signs Posted During the Cold War?
subtitle: Early 1950s efforts to prepare Americans for nuclear war included the erection of signs giving advance notice of highway closures in the event of attack.
author: David Emery
statement: During the Cold War, road signs were posted outside major metropolitan areas warning that specific highways would be closed to civilian traffic in the event of enemy attack.

title: Did a Man in Sweden Die From Penis Enhancement Surgery?
subtitle: News articles accurately recount a real case published in the Journal of Forensic Sciences.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: A man in Stockholm, Sweden died from a fat embolism after undergoing penis enlargement surgery.

title: Were King Cobras Shipped to Los Angeles in Snack Containers?
subtitle: A man was arrested on suspicion of smuggling cobras and other reptiles into the United States via Los Angeles.
author: Bethania Palma
statement: Venomous king cobra snakes were found stashed in snack food containers.

title: Did a Football Coach Say 'Act Like You've Been There Before'?
subtitle: An old quote about touchdown celebrations has been attributed to a number of coaches, including Joe Paterno, Paul Brown, and Vince Lombardi.
author: Dan Evon
statement: Penn State's Joe Paterno said "when you get into the end zone, act like you've been there before."

title: Can Veterans Shop Online at Military Exchange Stores?
subtitle: Thousands of veterans have applied to make use of the program prior to its November 2017 launch.
author: Arturo Garcia
statement: Military veterans who received honorable discharges are eligible to shop online at military exchanges.

title: Is a Wisconsin Company Offering to Microchip its Employees?
subtitle: River Falls-based Three Square Market is giving its workers the option of voluntarily having a microchip implanted in their hands.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: In July 2017, Three Square Market announced it was offering employees the option of having a microchip implanted in their hands.

title: The Origin of Graham Crackers
subtitle: Were graham crackers named for a man who believed unhealthy diet led to sexual excess?
author: David Mikkelson
statement: Graham crackers were named for a man who believed unhealthy diet led to sexual excess.

title: Finnish Researchers Set to Start Type 1 Diabetes Vaccine Trials?
subtitle: Scientists at Finnish universities are targeting a strand of viruses linked to Type 1 diabetes, and human trials for a vaccine will begin in 2018.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: In July 2017, it was announced that Finnish researchers would begin human trials of a Type 1 diabetes vaccine in 2018.

title: Bear Rides in Motorcycle Sidecar?
subtitle: A video showing a bear riding in a sidecar of a motorcycle may beggar belief, but it is genuine.
author: Dan Evon
statement: A video shows a bear riding in the sidecar of a motorcycle.

title: Did President Trump Say 'Eventually We Will Get Something Done'?
subtitle: The president made the comment, which was captured by a Fox News graphic, in regards to health care.
author: Bethania Palma
statement: President Donald Trump said "eventually we will get something done."

title: The 'Untitled' Byrds Album
subtitle: How Columbia Records mistakenly released a Byrds album without a title due to a miscommunication.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: Columbia Records mistakenly released a Byrds album without a title.

title: Racist Product Color Descriptions
subtitle: Modern products still sometimes bear labels and descriptions that include a color named for a racial pejorative.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: Modern products still sometimes bear labels and descriptions that include a color named for a racial pejorative.

title: Concrete Arrows Across the U.S.
subtitle: The U.S. landscape is still dotted with enormous concrete arrows that guided early airmail pilots across the country.
author: Snopes Staff
statement: Large concrete arrows set on the ground guided early airmail pilots across the U.S.

title: Was a Home Depot Employee Fired for Helping Police Stop a Kidnapping?
subtitle: The company offered Dillon Reagan his job back after his case garnered widespread attention online.
author: Arturo Garcia
statement: An Oregon man was fired from his job at Home Depot after helping police stop a kidnapping.

title: Did MAD Magazine Lampoon Donald Trump in 1992?
subtitle: The satirical publication got a two-decade head start on rubbing in the Donald's financial issues.
author: Dan Evon
statement: A cartoon lampooning Donald Trump over his lack of business acumen was published in a 1992 issue of Mad Magazine.

title: Does Donald Trump Have Fake 'Time' Magazine Covers Displayed at His Resorts?
subtitle: The magazine has reportedly requested that the faux covers promoting Trump's television show be taken down.
author: Arturo Garcia
statement: Fake "Time" magazine covers featuring Donald Trump were found at several of his golf resorts.

title: Did Ayn Rand Receive Social Security Benefits?
subtitle: The "Atlas Shrugged" author called government handouts "immoral," but there is evidence that she accepted Social Security benefits in her later years - and that it was consistent with her worldview to do so.
author: David Emery
statement: Despite arguing that government benefits constitute an immoral redistribution of wealth, Ayn Rand received Social Security payouts later in life.

title: Can the Bite of a 'Reverse Zombie' Tick Make You Allergic to Red Meat?
subtitle: More commonly known as the lone star tick, this unnerving arachnid can transmit an illness with symptoms similar to Lyme disease, as well as a substance that can cause an allergy to red meat.
author: David Emery
statement: The bite of a rare breed of tick most commonly called the lone star tick can cause itching, stomach cramps, breathing difficulties, and an allergic reaction to red meat.

title: Does Jon Ossoff Live Outside Georgia's Sixth Congressional District?
subtitle: The Democratic candidate has drawn criticism online from President Donald Trump for living just outside the district boundary, but he is not legally required to live within the region he represents.
author: Arturo Garcia
statement: Jon Ossoff is running to represent Georgia's sixth congressional district while living outside its boundaries.

title: Bringing a Gun to a Knife Fight
subtitle: Scott Baio asserted during a July 2016 MSNBC appearance that President Obama once said if [Republicans] "bring a knife" to a fight, [Democrats] should "bring a gun."
author: Kim LaCapria
statement: President Obama once said that if your opponents bring a (rhetorical) knife to a fight, you should bring a gun.

title: Did a German Woman Get Fined for Sharing a Meme on Facebook?
subtitle: A Breitbart article accurately reports the fining of a Berlin woman under Germany's strict hate speech laws.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: A German woman was fined €1,350 for sharing an anti-migrant meme on her Facebook page.

title: Making Cents
subtitle: U.S. pennies now cost considerably more than one cent each to manufacture.
author: Snopes Staff
statement: U.S. pennies now cost considerably more than one cent each to manufacture.

title: Man Mowed Lawn During Tornado?
subtitle: A photograph showing a man mowing his lawn while a funnel cloud rages behind him appears to be completely genuine.
author: Dan Evon
statement: A photograph shows a man mowing his lawn during a tornado.

title: Will Texting 'FOOD' Help Provide Free Summer Meals for Children?
subtitle: A viral message on social media contained accurate information about how to access food for kids this summer.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: Texting "FOOD" to 877-877 will provide a nearby location where free meals are available for children during the summer.

title: Letter Exchange Between Law Firm and Cleveland Browns
subtitle: A lawyer received a caustic response after complaining to the Cleveland Browns about fans' throwing paper airplanes during the team's home NFL games.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: A lawyer received a caustic response after complaining to the Cleveland Browns about fans' throwing paper airplanes during the team's home NFL games.

title: Is the Trump Administration Selling Subscription 'Big League Boxes'?
subtitle: E-mail screenshots touting boxes of Trump campaign merchandise were presumed by some readers to be either hoax or satire - but they're real.
author: Kim LaCapria
statement: In May 2017 President Trump launched a monthly "Big League Box" subscription for campaign merchandise.

title: Drano Bottle Bombs
subtitle: A viral alert warns about neighborhood residents finding unexploded 'bottle bombs' in their yards.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: Plastic soda bottles left in unsuspecting residents' yards may be bottle bombs.

title: Did Donald Trump Claim Global Warming Is a Hoax?
subtitle: Donald Trump and his campaign refused to acknowledge instances of his referring to global warming/climate change as a "hoax." What does the public record show?
author: David Emery
statement: Donald Trump has called global warming a "hoax" on multiple occasions.

title: Did Presidents Obama and Trump Write Wildly Different Entries in the Yad Yashem Guestbook?
subtitle: An image showing what President Trump and former President Obama wrote in the Yad Yashem guest book is accurate.
author: Dan Evon
statement: An image accurately depicts what President Trump and President Obama wrote in the Yad Yashem guest book.

title: Did a 1922 Article Warn of Oceans Warming?
subtitle: A newspaper article warning that climate change was melting Arctic ice and disrupting wildlife was published nearly a century ago.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: A 1922 newspaper article reported that "radical change in climatic conditions" was melting Arctic ice and disrupting wildlife.

title: Did Masai Tribespeople Donate 14 Cows to the United States After 9/11?
subtitle: A popular internet meme holding that members of the Masai tribe donated cows to the United States after the 11 September 2001 terrorist attacks is accurate.
author: Dan Evon
statement: The Masai Tribe donated 14 cows to the United States after 9/11.

title: Did Disney Fake Lemming Deaths for the Nature Documentary 'White Wilderness'?
subtitle: Lemmings don't commit mass suicide, so filmmakers had to use various camera tricks to capture scenes of them supposedly plunging to their deaths.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: Filmmakers staged lemming death scenes for the Disney nature documentary

title: Was Zomato Hit by Hackers?
subtitle: The restaurant review web site and app confirmed that data for millions of users was compromised.
author: Arturo Garcia
statement: The restaurant review website Zomato suffered an attack that compromised 17 million users' data

title: Trump Touches Glowing Orb in Saudi Arabia?
subtitle: The real significance of a photograph of President Trump and Saudi leaders touching a glowing orb was lost on Internet jokesters.
author: Dan Evon
statement: A photograph shows President Trump and Saudi leaders touching a glowing orb.

title: Handy Excuses for Nixon Backers?
subtitle: A 1973 satirical column offering familiar-sounding responses to criticisms of the Nixon Administration's Watergate scandal is authentic.
author: Alex Kasprak
statement: A 1973 column by humorist Art Buchwald, which provided canned responses for people supporting Nixon as the Watergate scandal grew, is authentic.

title: Did Richard Nixon Write a Letter Predicting Donald Trump's Success in Politics?
subtitle: A 1987 missive from the former president said his wife, Pat, had seen Trump on television and predicted he would be a "winner" if he decided to run for office.
author: David Emery
statement: Former President Richard Nixon sent a letter to Trump predicting he would be a successful politician whenever he decided to run for office.

title: Did a Texas Girl Need Surgery After Choking on Part of a Fidget Spinner?
subtitle: A woman wrote a harrowing story on Facebook about her daughter's needing surgery after swallowing a piece of the popular toy.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: A Texas girl required surgery after she swallowed part of a fidget spinner while cleaning it.

title: Can the New Drug 'Gray Death' Be Transmitted Through the Air?
subtitle: A potent new mix of drugs includes carfentanil, which is used to tranquilize elephants.
author: Bethania Palma
statement: A dangerous new drug known as "gray death" can kill through the air and skin contact.

title: Did 'No Whites Allowed' Signs Exist in the Segregated South?
subtitle: The existence of "colored only" businesses under Jim Crow laws in the southern United States comes as a shock to those unfamiliar with the history.
author: David Emery
statement: During the Jim Crow era of racial segregation in the American South, some businesses posted "colored only, no whites allowed" signs over their doors.

title: Was the Horse's Head in 'The Godfather' Real?
subtitle: The "horse's head" scene in epic film "The Godfather" is one of Hollywood's most memorable, but was the item merely a prop or the real thing?
author: Kim LaCapria
statement: The horse's head that appeared in an iconic scene in the film

title: Did the ACLU Issue a Warning for People Traveling to Texas?
subtitle: The American Civil Liberties Union did issue a warning about travel to Texas, but it is not the same as U.S. Department of State advisories.
author: Kim LaCapria
statement: In May 2017, the ACLU issued a warning for Americans traveling to Texas.

title: Did a Millionaire Fire His Bank Because It Did Not Validate Parking?
subtitle: Next time a clerk looks down his nose at you, tell him about John Barrier and the Washington State bank.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: A customer closed out his million-dollar account after his bank refused to validate a 50-cent parking ticket.

title: Can You Have Your Ashes Mailed to Congress?
subtitle: A Washington, D.C., college student created a web site for people planning a posthumous protest of the American Health Care Act.
author: Arturo Garcia
statement: If you die, you can send your ashes to legislators as one final act of protest.

title: Was a Woman Prosecuted for Laughing During Jeff Sessions' Confirmation Hearing?
subtitle: Desiree Fairooz, a member of the protest group Code Pink, was charged with disorderly conduct after laughing during the introduction of Attorney General nominee Jeff Sessions.
author: David Emery
statement: Code Pink member Desiree Fairooz was prosecuted for disorderly conduct after she laughed during Attorney General Jeff Sessions's confirmation hearing.

title: Did Melania Trump 'Like' a Tweet Lampooning Her Relationship With President Trump?
subtitle: The personal Twitter account for Melania Trump "liked" (then quickly "unliked") a post speculating about her relationship with her husband.
author: Dan Evon
statement: Melania Trump "liked" a tweet that poked fun at her relationship with her husband, President Donald Trump.

title: Did a Trump Golf Course Commemorate a Civil War Battle That Never Happened?
subtitle: A historically inaccurate plaque on a Trump-owned golf course commemorates a Civil War battle along the banks of the Potomac that never took place.
author: Kim LaCapria
statement: A plaque displayed on a golf course owned by President Trump commemorates a Civil War battle that never happened.

title: The Maiken and the Birth of an Island
subtitle: Photographs taken from a yacht show the formation of a small island via a volcanic eruption at sea.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: Photographs taken from a yacht show the formation of an island via a volcanic eruption at sea.

title: Michigan Threatens Beavers Over Dams?
subtitle: The state of Michigan once threatened local beavers with a $10,000 per day fine for failing to remove their dams.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: The state of Michigan threatened local beavers with a $10,000 per day fine for failing to remove their dams.

title: Luxury 'Fyre' Music Festival in the Bahamas Descends Into Chaos?
subtitle: Amid reports of stranded attendees and no refunds, some are hinting that the entire festival was a scam.
author: Bethania Palma
statement: The Fyre Festival was oversold and rapidly descended into chaos, leaving attendees stranded due to its last-minute cancellation.

title: Did Jeff Sessions Say He's Amazed a Judge 'On an Island in the Pacific' Can Block Executive Orders?
subtitle: The Trump administration's Attorney General expressed his amazement on a radio talk show.
author: Bethania Palma
statement: Attorney General Jeff Sessions said he's amazed a Hawaiian judge "sitting on an island in the Pacific' can block executive orders.

title: The Origins of 420
subtitle: The story of how the code '420' entered drug parlance as a term signifying the time to light up a joint.
author: Snopes Staff
statement: The term '420' entered drug parlance as a term signifying the time to light up a joint.

title: Did a Nazi Leader Say Convincing People to Support War is 'Simple'?
subtitle: Nazi Luftwaffe commander Hermann Goering was one of the highest-ranking Nazis who survived to be captured and put on trial for war crimes.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: Nazi Luftwaffe commander Hermann Goering  proclaimed that although "the people don't want war,"  they "can always be brought to the bidding of their leaders."

title: Cent to College
subtitle: How an enterprising college student financed his education by soliciting one-cent donations.
author: Snopes Staff
statement: An enterprising college student solicited one-cent donations to finance his education.

title: Was Neil Gorsuch Unanimously Confirmed in 2006?
subtitle: The Supreme Court nominee was unanimously confirmed to the 10th Circuit Court of Appeals in 2006 - by some of the very people criticizing his nomination to the Supreme Court in 2017.
author: Dan Evon
statement: Judge Neil Gorsuch was unanimously confirmed to the 10th Circuit Court of Appeals in 2006.

title: Is a 'Do Not Cross This Field' Bull Warning Sign Real?
subtitle: Although a photograph showing a bull warning sign is frequently shared with a claim that it was digitally altered, the sign is actually real.
author: Dan Evon
statement: A photograph shows a humorous sign warning people not to cross a field due to the presence of a bull.

title: Is a Maine Crematorium Offering Free Cremations?
subtitle: Downeast Direct Cremations has offered the service for free to contest winners, attracting the attention of meme groups.
author: Arturo Garcia
statement: A crematorium in Maine offered its services for free to contest winners.

title: Does This Picture Show a Pregnant Melania Trump Posing on a Jet?
subtitle: "The Donald's very pregnant wife is trumping the slew of expecting stars who've been photographed before her ..."
author: Dan Evon
statement: A photograph shows Melania Trump posing in front of a jet while pregnant.

title: Did Democrats Tweet an Altered Version of a Socialist Party Poster?
subtitle: A DNC tweet celebrating a Republican setback featured an altered version of a message from the Party for Socialism and Liberation.
author: Arturo Garcia
statement: A Democratic National Committee tweet included an altered version of a Socialist party's poster

title: Could Cipro and Other Fluoroquinolone Antibiotics Cause Irreversible Tendon Damage?
subtitle: Though still rare, the potential risks are significant enough for the Food and Drug Administration to suggest limiting these drugs' use to cases of absolute necessity.
author: Alex Kasprak
statement: The FDA has updated its warnings for - and recommended limitations on - prescribing a class of antibiotics called fluoroquinolones, citing potentially irreversible side-effects including tendon damage and rupture.

title: Does Roger Stone Have a Tattoo of Richard Nixon on His Back?
subtitle: A photograph seemingly shows American political consultant and conspiracy theory spreader Roger Stone with an unusual tattoo on his back.
author: Dan Evon
statement: American political consultant Roger Stone has a tattoo of Richard Nixon on his back.

title: European Parental Leave Benefits
subtitle: Senator Bernie Sanders' office released an image showing how the U.S. 'lags' behind Canada, Norway, and Germany on the issue of parental leave.
author: Arturo Garcia
statement: Canada, Norway, and Germany each offer federally paid family leave programs ranging from 35 weeks to 1 year in length.

title: Are 'Blue Balls' a Real Thing?
subtitle: Yes, but it is neither an emergency nor a reason to pressure a partner into sex -- the solution to this condition can be found in the sufferer's own hand.
author: Alex Kasprak
statement: Prolonged sexual arousal in men without an ejaculation can cause pain, a condition colloquially referred to as "blue balls".
